steps.title: Leave the flax seed whole.
steps.content: Leave the flax seed whole. Small flax seeds are the perfect size for adding to your food when whole. Make sure you chew the seeds thoroughly to aid in their digestion and access the nutritional benefits flax seeds have to offer. Whole flax seed can be kept fresh for 6-12 months at room temperature, and one year in the refrigerator.

steps.title: Grind the flax seed.
steps.content: Grind the flax seed. The Omega-3 fatty acids present in flax seed are located inside the seeds and therefore the seeds need to be opened to access the nutritional value. You can grind the flax seed using a coffee or spice grinder to ensure that you are reaping the benefits of flax seed. Ground flax can be stored for one week in a room temperature setting or for up to two months in the refrigerator. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Take a flax seed oil supplement.
steps.content: Take a flax seed oil supplement. If you want to get the benefits of flax seed without the taste or hassle of adding it to your food, simply purchase flax seed supplements and take one pill daily.

steps.title: Drink flax seed oil.
steps.content: Drink flax seed oil. You can also buy flax seed in its liquid oil form and add it to your beverage of choice. Flax seed oil has the same nutty taste as the seeds themselves but without the seedy texture.

steps.title: Use two to three tablespoons of whole seed per serving.
steps.content: Use two to three tablespoons of whole seed per serving. If you are simply adding the flax seed to an individual meal, this ratio will give you a beneficial serving without affecting the flavor of your food.

steps.title: Put flax seed in your morning cereal or oatmeal.
steps.content: Put flax seed in your morning cereal or oatmeal. Flax seed gives your boring bowl a fresh, nutty flavor. Try adding some fresh berries in to complement the added flavor of the flax seed.

steps.title: Add flax to yogurt or applesauce.
steps.content: Add flax to yogurt or applesauce. Add whole seeds for a nice texture that boosts the health value of your creamy snack.

steps.title: Mix them into bread or muffin batter.
steps.content: Mix them into bread or muffin batter. Simply pick your favorite muffin or bread recipe and add about 1/4-cup of flax seed per batch. The final product will gain a nice crunch and an interesting texture. You can also use ground flax seed and water as a replacement for eggs. For one egg, the ratio is one tablespoon of flax seed to three tablespoons of water. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Add flax seed to a smoothie.
steps.content: Add flax seed to a smoothie. Fruit smoothies are nicely complemented by the addition of nutty flax seed. Boost the fiber power in your smoothie by adding about one tablespoon per serving.

steps.title: Put flax seed in your french toast.
steps.content: Put flax seed in your french toast. Add flax seed to your french toast dip and allow the flax to coat the bread before pan frying it. Not only does the flax add a nice crunch, but the flavor goes perfectly with a traditional french toast recipe. You can use either whole flax seeds or ground flax.

steps.title: Make flax seed cookies.
steps.content: Make flax seed cookies. Add flax seed to your favorite trail mix cookies. Cookies with dried fruit, nuts, oats, and other chunky ingredients are nicely complimented by flax seed.

steps.title: Sprinkle flax seed on your salad.
steps.content: Sprinkle flax seed on your salad. Nuts are often a nice addition to a salad, and flax seed can give the same flavor effect. Dark greens like spinach taste especially good with flax.

steps.title: Coat meat or vegetables in a flax seed crust.
steps.content: Coat meat or vegetables in a flax seed crust. Add flax seed to your usual crusting mix with other complementary spices to add crunch and flavor to your choice of meat or vegetable.

steps.title: Mix flax seed into your meatballs, meatloaf and casseroles.
steps.content: Mix flax seed into your meatballs, meatloaf and casseroles. If you really have to disguise the flax seed to get your family members to eat it, put it in a complex dish like one of these to get the benefits without even knowing that the seeds are there. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Make savory flax seed bread, crackers or chips.
steps.content: Make savory flax seed bread, crackers or chips. Add whole flax seeds to any of these carbohydrate products to boost the health value of your meal.
